newsitem.title: HONG KONG: HK's SCMP survives tough yr relatively unscathed.
newsitem.headline: HK's SCMP survives tough yr relatively unscathed.

text.p: Hong Kong newspaper publisher South China Morning Post (Holdings) Ltd on Monday posted a 20 percent increase in 1995/96 net profit with the help of gains from the sale of its old headquarters building.
SCMP's operating profits shrank during a trying year for publishers, but the company said it saw a better year ahead.

"We expect an improvement in the Hong Kong economy in the coming year largely due to positive signs in the retail and property market, a lower unemployment figure, and an anticipated increase of visitors to Hong Kong," company said.
Together with an expected drop in newsprint costs and improved results from its new subsidiary TVE (Holdings) Ltd, that would provide for a "rewarding year ahead", it said.

SCMP announced a 20 percent jump in net profit to HK$695.87 million (US$90 million) in the year to June 30, helped by an exceptional gain of HK$181 million from sale of its old headquarters building in Hong Kong's Quarry Bay district.
But prior to exceptionals and contribution from associates, operating profit fell to HK$602.34 million from HK$692.71 million.

Analysts said SCMP, which publishes the English-language South China Morning Post daily in Hong Kong, rode through a difficult year relatively unscathed, and added it was likely to turn in better results in the coming year.
"In light of the difficult conditions, SCMP has done fairly well and better than the market expected," said Robert Fong, a media analyst with James Capel.
Analysts said Hong Kong newspapers faced an extraordinarily trying 1995/96 due to steep rises in newsprint costs, a downturn in advertising and an aggressive newspaper price war.
The tough times were seen in the closure of several Chinese language newspapers, while the Oriental Press Group shut down its English-language daily Eastern Express in June.

In August, Oriental Press reported a 94 percent drop in net profit to HK$25.08 million for the year to March 31, while publisher Ming Pao Enterprise Corp Ltd plunged into the red by HK$9.39 million for the same period.

"I would say the (SCMP) results are better than what many expected...I'm sure the Chinese press would have liked to have come out with only a 15-20 percent downturn in operating profit," said another analyst, who declined to be named.
Analysts also expected the group to turn in better results in the coming year with the turnaround in advertising spending and lower newsprint costs.
